snippet.textDisplay:
My rant is just on how inferior Windows is from a programmer's perspective. I've been fighting to get software to compile with Visual Studio the last few days. The amount of bullshit and non-standard platform specific crap I've had to add to my build scripts just to appease MSVC has made me want to blow my brains out. Windows' dynamic linker doesn't support backlinking either, like POSIX does. So I have to link all my extensions with most of the same DLLs as the program they plug into, though that's more of just a nuisance. And a pragma in the source to dynamically link to a DLL? Really? I knew about it for some time but didn't realize how few alternative options you have when using MSVC for your toolchain.
Not to mention dependency hell is 1000% worse with MSVC, since there's no good package management and everything in NuGet is old and crusty and/or infected. And lastly, even if you can use MinGW like I usually do, some newer Win32 functions are not available due to a lack of maintenance. And then you get to deal with the various libstdc++/msvc runtime collisions.
snippet.textOriginal:
My rant is just on how inferior Windows is from a programmer's perspective. I've been fighting to get software to compile with Visual Studio the last few days. The amount of bullshit and non-standard platform specific crap I've had to add to my build scripts just to appease MSVC has made me want to blow my brains out. Windows' dynamic linker doesn't support backlinking either, like POSIX does. So I have to link all my extensions with most of the same DLLs as the program they plug into, though that's more of just a nuisance. And a pragma in the source to dynamically link to a DLL? Really? I knew about it for some time but didn't realize how few alternative options you have when using MSVC for your toolchain.
Not to mention dependency hell is 1000% worse with MSVC, since there's no good package management and everything in NuGet is old and crusty and/or infected. And lastly, even if you can use MinGW like I usually do, some newer Win32 functions are not available due to a lack of maintenance. And then you get to deal with the various libstdc++/msvc runtime collisions.

snippet.textDisplay:
I struggle with windows. On one hand it’s a great OS but on the other it’s riddled with bloatware and ads. I’d rather pay for the OS (which I did!) and not get adverts.

I think the freemium model is great, it means that people who can’t afford to pay money for something can still get the benefits from it but I think for it to really work there should also be a version without the freemium stuff that you pay for.

It’s one of the reasons I stick with Apple even though I’m not a fan of the Mac hardware.
snippet.textOriginal:
I struggle with windows. On one hand it’s a great OS but on the other it’s riddled with bloatware and ads. I’d rather pay for the OS (which I did!) and not get adverts. 

I think the freemium model is great, it means that people who can’t afford to pay money for something can still get the benefits from it but I think for it to really work there should also be a version without the freemium stuff that you pay for. 

It’s one of the reasons I stick with Apple even though I’m not a fan of the Mac hardware.

snippet.textDisplay:
Yes, it has absolutely nothing to do with the fact that popular Linux Operating systems are catching up in terms of ease of use and software that can be used for different tasks.

There are different country governments at the very least threatening to switch to Linux Operating systems because they would be cheaper and more secure alternatives, also businesses are always looking for excuses to not spend money, no constant buying of expensive license keys. So of course Microsoft is going to cave to the demands and no longer extort money from everyone just to have the ability to use Windows, they don't have a choice.
snippet.textOriginal:

There are different country governments at the very least threatening to switch to Linux Operating systems because they would be cheaper and more secure alternatives, also businesses are always looking for excuses to not spend money, no constant buying of expensive license keys. So of course Microsoft is going to cave to the demands and no longer extort money from everyone just to have the ability to use Windows, they don't have a choice.

snippet.textDisplay:
Lol it looks like you are not even understand to basic principles of licence agreements. At first as i know all non activated windows versions worked this way! It does not mean it is legal and not breaking EULA. Current windows 10 on official stores is still around 100 dollars. At the end of the day, there are not even valid those cheap dollars activation keys although its all activated and working through official microsoft sites because in final countdown you are still breaking EULA by not paying regular price!! If product is working over contrary to EULA it does not mean developers are giving its copies for free. It does not mean anything.
I'm not even mentioning they surely don't care about personal licences as most of cash flow is in corporate sphere where majority of users will have a legal software due to high EULA sanctions.....

snippet.textDisplay: I have a Win7 Dell laptop. About 2 years ago, after the free upgrade ended, I heard you could still update some computers, so I tried, but was unsuccessful. Last month, with Win7 support coming to an end, I tried again, and was able to update. I didn't update during the free period because 7 is better than 10. (XP was the best Windows.) But I left the computer in the car for a few hours in the middle of July, and it wasn't running well. So I needed to reinstall, and didn't make an OS backup.
snippet.textOriginal: I have a Win7 Dell laptop. About 2 years ago, after the free upgrade ended, I heard you could still update some computers, so I tried, but was unsuccessful. Last month, with Win7 support coming to an end, I tried again, and was able to update. I didn't update during the free period because 7 is better than 10. (XP was the best Windows.) But I left the computer in the car for a few hours in the middle of July, and it wasn't running well. So I needed to reinstall, and didn't make an OS backup.
